Summary I'm currently working as a Test Engineer for Errigal Operations Software limited after finishing fourth year of BSc Applied Computing (Level 8) in Waterford Institute of Technology. I have studied a range of Modules including Programming, Security, Networking, Games Design, Cryptography, AI, Databases and Ethics. I have experienced many different programming languages including Java, Python, Perl, PHP, Ruby and MySQL. Many of my modules have been taught through Linux, giving me a good knowledge of the Linux command line and tools. I decided to take the Networking stream and from this I have explored many aspects of Networking, from basic switching and routing to configuring Instances in AWS through Python. My FYP is also Networking based and revolves around the Openstack Cloud Computing service.  
 
I've previously worked for Intel on three separate occasions. All times I was situated in Shannon. I've worked with Client services, fixing computers and dealing with client issues and I have also worked in a software team. My job was primarily based around Software Defined Networking and working with the Cloud Operating Software, Openstack. 
 
I currently manage my own fashion, beauty and fitness Blog which allows me to keep in touch with web design whilst still enjoying my hobby. Summary "Know something about everything-rather than everything about something"​ 
That's one of the motto's I try to live by. At least in the software engineering industry. That also forms the core of my experience in the same. 
Throughout my 4+ years in the industry, I have been involved right from requirements gathering from potential clients, budget estimation, software design and development, configuration management and release, manual testing, and test automation. 
I have been called a jack of all trades. While some may argue that that's not quite desirable, I believe , with this all-round knowledge of the SDLC, I can bring more value into any project that I carry out. 
 
I started out in game porting and moved through quite a few technology. I've also worked on BREW(which I believe is extinct now). Most of my initial career was spent in SCM and release engineering after which I moved to software development. 
I've dabbled in android a bit and more recently , in grad school,I am trying to educate myself on web development using the MEAN stack(Its a work in progress). 
I have been fascinated with Big Data and that would probably be my next destination. 
 
In grad school, going to hackathons kind of became a hobby. It wasn't what you made, but what you learnt from it that excited me the most. I learnt a lot from it, and I still carry fond memories of the sleepless nights stringing together code that would just about work in the morning!  
 
Looking forward to much more of those in my final semester in Spring 2016! Summary "Know something about everything-rather than everything about something"​
